facts.text: A partnership styled P.K.N. was carrying on money-lending business in several towns in India and also in the Federated States of Malaya.

facts.text: P.K.N. firm acquired rubber estates and other immovables in the Districts of Muar and Segamat in the Federated States of Malaya.

anchor.surface_text: ya. In the companyrse of its business the P.K.N. firm acquired rubber estates and other immovables in the Districts of Muar and Segamat in the Federated States of Malaya.

facts.text: On December 4, 1937, a private limited company was registered in the name of P.K.N. Company Ltd. under the Pudukottai Company Regulation V of 1929 with head office at Viswanathapuram in Pudukottai territories.

Company Ltd. - hereinafter called the companypany - under the Pudukottai Company Regulation V of 1929 with its head office at Viswanathapuram, in the territories of His Highness the Maharaja of Pudukottai.

facts.text: Share capital of the company was of the face value of 6,60,000 Malayan dollars.

facts.text: Between March 23, 1939, and July 8, 1939, an area of more than 3,000 acres of rubber plantations, several houses and open plots of land were transferred to the company for 16,50,000 Malayan dollars.

anchor.surface_text: Between March 23, 1939, and July 8, 1939, an area of more than 3,000 acres of rubber plantations, several houses and open plots of land, which were the assets of the P.K.N. firm, were transferred to the companypany for an aggregate companysideration of 16,50,000 Malayan dollars.

facts.text: Company allotted shares of face value 6,60,000 Malayan dollars to partners of P.K.N. firm and balance remained as debt due to the firm.

anchor.surface_text: In companysideration of the transfer of these properties, the companypany allotted shares of the face value of 6,60,000 Malayan dollars to the partners of the firm of P. K. N. and the balance remained outstanding as a debt due by the Company to the firm of P.K.N.

facts.text: On March 14, 1941 the Company purchased a rubber estate called the Lee Estate for 2,62,655 Malayan dollars.

facts.text: On July 7, 1941 the Company purchased for 5,000 Malayan dollars a house in co-ownership with another firm.

facts.text: In the year 1941 and 1942 some of the properties acquired from the firm of P. K. N. were sold by the Company.

facts.text: Between 1942 and 1945 the territory of Malaya was under occupation by the Japanese forces and some houses belonging to the company were destroyed by fire.

facts.text: After 1945 some more lands admeasuring approximately 700 acres in the aggregate were sold by the Company.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Pudukottai, assessed the company as a dealer in real estate and brought profits of 34,272 Malayan dollars to tax in 1949-50 and 40,613 in 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: the companypany was assessed by the Income-tax Officer, Pudukottai, as a dealer in real estate and profits amounting to 34,272 Malayan dollars and 40,613 Malayan dollars were brought to tax in the assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal set aside the assessment orders for 1949-50 and 1950-51 holding profits were of capital nature.

anchor.surface_text: But the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal set aside the orders. The Tribunal observed that the activities of the companypany outside India were limited to the holding of properties, and deriving income therefrom, and that the properties did number companye to the companypany in the companyrse of its money- lending business, number companyld it be said that they were acquired for the purpose of resale at a profit, and that the companypany was formed in order to take over these properties and it would be far from companyrect to say that the properties taken over were intended to be turned into stock-in-trade, and therefore profits realised by sale of the properties were of capital nature.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed the company for 1951-52 on total profit of 1,41,326 Malayan dollars from sale of immovable properties.

anchor.surface_text: Before the order of the Tribunal was pronounced, the Income-tax Officer assessed the companypany for the assessment year 1951-52 on a total profit of 1,41,326 Malayan dollars earned from the sale of immovable properties.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the ITO order for 1951-52 in appeal.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal confirmed the AAC order for 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal companyfirmed the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner observing that all the material facts were number brought to the numberice of the Tribunal at the hearing of the appeals in respect of the earlier years.

facts.text: High Court of Madras under section 66(2) of Income-tax Act directed Tribunal to refer the question on whether surplus of 1,41,326 Malayan dollars was income chargeable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, pursuant to a direction of the High Court of Madras under section 66 2  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, the Tribunal referred the following question for the opinion of the High Court Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the surplus of 1,41,326 realised by the assessee-company by the sale of some of its estates and properties held by it in Malaya was income chargeable to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: High Court answered in favour of the company holding the amount was not income chargeable under Indian Income-tax Act.

XVI  To sell, mortgage, let, exchange, manage, improve, cultivate, develop, dispose of, turn to account or otherwise deal with all or any part of the properties, rights and privileges of the companypany upon any terms, and for any companysideration.

holdings.text: The surplus of 1,41,326 realised by the assessee-company by the sale of some of its estates and properties held by it in Malaya was not income chargeable to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the surplus of 1,41,326 realised by the assessee-company by the sale of some of its estates and properties held by it in Malaya was income chargeable to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revenue failed onus; primary activity planters with incidental sales over years due to necessity/opportunity; no fresh acquisitions post-1941; properties taken as investment not stock-in-trade; distinguished trading cases.

holdings.text: The question whether profit in a transaction has arisen out of an adventure in the nature of trade is a mixed question of law and fact depending upon the collective effect of all relevant materials.

anchor.surface_text: the question whether profit in a transaction has arisen out of an adventure in the nature of trade is a mixed question of law and fact. It was further observed the question whether a transaction is an adventure in the nature of trade must depend upon the collective effect of all the relevant materials brought on the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistently held by Supreme Court; general criteria like relation to business, subdivision, magnitude relevant but not presumptive for land.

holdings.text: It is for the revenue to establish that the profit earned in a transaction is within the taxing provision and liable to be taxed as income.

anchor.surface_text: it is for the revenue to establish that the profit earned in a transactions is within the taxing provision and is on that account liable to be taxed as income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly from recent SC precedent in Janki Ram Bahadur Ram v. CIT.

holdings.text: Existence of power in the memorandum of association to sell or turn into account, dispose of, or deal with properties has no decisive bearing on whether profits are capital accretion or revenue income.

anchor.surface_text: Existence of power in the memorandum of association to sell or turn into account, dispose of, or deal with the properties and rights of all kinds, has no decisive bearing on the question whether the profits arising therefrom are capital accretion or revenue income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Powers relevant but substance over form; cited Karanpura Development, Kishan Prasad precedents distinguishing ownership vs trading.

holdings.text: But these facts found by the Tribunal do not, in our judgment, justify the inference that the acquisition of the estates was for the purpose of carrying on business in real estate.

anchor.surface_text: But these facts found by the Tribunal do number, in our judgment, justify the inference that the acquisition of the estates was for the purpose of carrying on business in real estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected revenue arguments on magnitude, borrowings, sales continuity, development; facts show no trading intent, primary planting business.

precedents.citation: Janki Ram Bahadur Ram v. Commissioner of Income- tax

anchor.surface_text: In a recent judgment, Janki Ram Bahadur Ram v. Commissioner of Income- tax, it was observed by this companyrt at page 24 it is for the revenue to establish that the profit earned in a transactions is within the taxing provision and is on that account liable to be taxed as income. The nature of the transaction must be determined on a companysideration of all the facts and circumstances which are brought on the record of the income-tax authorities.

precedents.case_name: Janki Ram Bahadur Ram v Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Burden on revenue to establish taxable income; nature of transaction determined on facts; mixed question of law and fact; criteria for adventure in nature of trade including relation to business, subdivision, magnitude, but land purchase not assumed trade; profit motive not decisive
precedents.cited_holding: it is for the revenue to establish that the profit earned in a transactions is within the taxing provision and is on that account liable to be taxed as income. The nature of the transaction must be determined on a companysideration of all the facts and circumstances... question whether a transaction is an adventure in the nature of trade must depend upon the companylective effect of all the relevant materials... general criteria indicating that certain facts have dominant significance...

precedents.citation: Karanpura Development Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1

anchor.surface_text: In delivering the judgment of this companyrt in Karanpura Development Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 Hidayatullah J. observed at Page 377 Ownership of property and leasing it out may be done as a part of business, or it may be done as land owner. Whether it is the one or the other must necessarily depend upon the object with which the act is done.

precedents.case_name: Karanpura Development Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Ownership of property and leasing may be as business or as owner depending on object; look to substance not form; company can own property as owner
precedents.cited_holding: Ownership of property and leasing it out may be done as a part of business, or it may be done as land owner. Whether it is the one or the other must necessarily depend upon the object with which the act is done. It is number that numbercompany can own property and enjoy it as property... In deciding whether a companypany dealt with its properties as owner, one must see number to the form which it gave to the transaction but to the substance of the matter.

precedents.citation: Kishan Prasad and Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2

anchor.surface_text: In Kishan Prasad and Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2 it was observed that the circumstance whether a transaction is or is number within the companypanys power has numberbearing on the nature of the transaction, or on the question whether the profits arising therefrom are capital accretion or revenue income.

precedents.case_name: Kishan Prasad and Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Whether transaction within company's powers has no bearing on whether profits are capital or revenue
precedents.cited_holding: the circumstance whether a transaction is or is number within the companypanys power has numberbearing on the nature of the transaction, or on the question whether the profits arising therefrom are capital accretion or revenue income.

precedents.citation: Raja J. Rameshwar Rao v. Commissioner of Income-tax 3

anchor.surface_text: Raja J. Rameshwar Rao v. Commissioner of Income-tax 3 was a case on the other side of the line. In that case a person acquired land with a view to selling it later after developing it and making the plots more attractive. This companyrt held, having regard to the circumstances, that the venture was in the nature of trade,

precedents.case_name: Raja J Rameshwar Rao v Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Acquisition of land to develop and sell later is adventure in nature of trade
precedents.cited_holding: a person acquired land with a view to selling it later after developing it and making the plots more attractive. This companyrt held... that the venture was in the nature of trade, and the assessee was dealing with land as his stock-in-trade and carrying on business and making profits.

precedents.citation: St. Aubyn Estates Ltd. v. Strick 4

anchor.surface_text: In St. Aubyn Estates Ltd. v.
